article.headline: Lady Tigers bounce back from loss to Vols
article.linkText: LSU never trails Mississippi, wins by 13
article.story:
NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) -- The LSU Lady Tigers (No. 14 ESPN/USA Today, No. 15 AP) needed to bounce back after ending the regular season being routed by Tennessee.

Mission accomplished.

Doneeka Hodges hit five of eight 3-pointers and scored 24 points to
help LSU down Mississippi 79-66 Friday in the quarterfinals
of the Southeastern Conference tournament. Acting head coach Pokey
Chatman said all the practice this week paid off, especially on
defense.

"It was important coming off the loss at Tennessee to establish
a defensive presence, and I think at halftime, they were shooting
27 percent from the field," Chatman said of the Lady Rebels.

The second-seeded Lady Tigers (23-6) never trailed as they
opened defense of their tournament title. They will play either No.
19 Auburn or No. 21 Vanderbilt in the semifinals Saturday night.

Seventh-seeded Mississippi (17-13) failed to advance past the
second round for the 11th straight year, and the Lady Rebels have
only themselves to blame because they didn't come close to keeping
pace with the SEC's best shooting team.

After Amber Watts tied the game at 2, the Lady Rebels missed 15
of their next 16 shots. They wound up shooting just 31.1 percent
(24-of-77), while LSU seemingly couldn't miss in hitting eight of
its first 11. The Lady Tigers, who had been averaging a league-high
46.8 percent, finished 29-of-60 (48.3 percent).

Ole Miss coach Carol Ross said the Lady Tigers opened the game
very aggressively and played like the defending champions.

"We had a tough little stretch there. Sometimes you can get
away with those stretches, but when you're playing great teams they
make you pay. LSU made us pay. They stepped up and really put their
foot on our throats, and I thought showed really great killer
instinct," Ross said.

Seimone Augustus added 20 points for LSU.

Armintie Price, the SEC's freshman of the year, led Ole Miss
with 18 points. Carletta Brown was held to 1-of-9 from the floor,
while Genice Terry was 1-of-15.

"We just kind of locked down and did what we're capable of
doing," Chatman said.

LSU coach Sue Gunter was not on the bench for the game, but
Chatman said she is in Nashville. Gunter has missed 14 games
because of a medical leave for acute bronchitis even though she has
been working with the Lady Tigers.

"We've been doing this from about Jan. 5th, so it's not
anything new," Chatman said. "I guess the newness kind of came
about because of the statement released a little while ago. She's
very much a part. You guys just don't see her."

Hodges hit her first three 3s, and then her bucket with 11:53
left put LSU up 19-6. Tywanna Inmon capped an 8-0 spurt to pull the
Lady Rebels within 27-21 with 6:18 left, then Augustus scored for
LSU and Amber Watts had a pair of free throws to make it 29-23.

That was as close as the Lady Rebels would get as Hodges hit
another 3, and Temeeka Johnson scored on a 3-point play. Ole Miss
lost Inmon a minute later when she hurt her left knee and had to be
carried off the court.

Chatman said Hodges benefitted from better passing offensively
that helped give the senior guard wide open looks.

Hodges hit her fifth 3 to give LSU a 43-26 halftime lead, and
the Lady Tigers had no problem improving to a perfect 23-0 when
leading at the half. They led by as much as 62-32 when Scholanda
Hoston scored with 11:36 remaining.

The Lady Rebels had one last 10-0 spurt to get within 62-42. But
LSU simply put back Hodges and Augustus back in the game, and
Hodges scored to end Mississippi's run.
